bestBHT.bht: These two olive trees and two candlesticks embody the faithful witnesses of God, signifying the Church's representative light-bearers. They draw their light from the Spirit, ministering for the Church's encouragement during times of apostasy. Standing before the Lord, they testify to His truth and are accepted in His sight, ready to act on His behalf. The witnesses freely impart the oil of grace and the Gospel's truth, shining as lights, continually transmitting the unction of the Holy One to others in the world.

Henry Alford: These are the two olive trees and the two candlesticks which stand before the Lord of the earth."
St. John has taken up and amplified the prophetic symbolism of Zechariah, carrying it on by the well-known figure of lights, as representing God’s testifying servants.
Who the two 'sons of oil' in the prophet were, whether Zerubbabel and Joshua, or the prophets Zechariah and Haggai, is of no import to our text here.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: The phrase alludes to Zechariah 4:10; Zechariah 4:14, 'the two anointed ones that stand by the Lord of the whole earth.' The article 'the' marks this allusion.
They are 'the two candlesticks,' not that they are the Church, the one candlestick, but as its representative light-bearers, and ministering for its encouragement in a time of apostasy.
The Church in both dispensations has no light in herself, but derives it from the Spirit through the witness of the twofold word, the two olive trees.
Albert Barnes: These are the two olive-trees... that stand by the Lord of the whole earth."
The sense would appear to be that it was through the pastors of the churches that the oil of grace which maintained the brightness of those mystic candlesticks, or the churches, was conveyed.
The meaning is, that they stood, as it were, in the very presence of God.
Marvin Vincent: Candlesticks. See Zechariah 4:0, and note on Matthew 10:15.
The God. Read kuriou the Lord. Compare Zechariah 4:14.
Philip Schaff: The figure is taken from Zechariah 4:0, with this difference, that there we have only one candlestick with an olive tree on either side of it, while here we have two candlesticks as well as two olive trees.
Clear indication is thus given that, whoever the two ‘witnesses’ may be, each combines in himself the functions both of the olive tree and of the candlestick.
Their ‘standing before the Lord’ indicates their acceptance in His sight and their readiness to act for Him.
Archibald T. Robertson: The two olive trees...In Zechariah 4:2; Zechariah 4:3; Zechariah 4:14 the lampstand or candlestick (λυχνια) is Israel, and the two olive trees apparently Joshua and Zerubbabel, but John makes his own use of this symbolism.
Here the two olive trees and the candlesticks are identical.

Standing (εστωτες). Masculine perfect active participle agreeing with ουτο instead of εστωσα (read by P and cursives) agreeing with ελαια κα λυχνια, even though α (feminine plural article) be accepted before ενωπιον του κυριου (before the Lord).
John Gill: Who may be compared to olive trees, because of the oil of grace, and the truth of it in them.
They freely impart their gifts, and the golden oil of the Gospel unto others.
Ministering unto him, enjoying his presence, and having his assistance, and being under his protection.
John Wesley: Being themselves full of the unction of the Holy One, they shall continually transmit the same to others also.
And the two candlesticks — Burning and shining lights.
Standing before the Lord of the earth — Always waiting on God, without the help of man, and asserting his right over the earth and all things therein.

bhtAttempts.bht: These two olive trees and the two candlesticks symbolize God's faithful witnesses who testify for Him. Like the prophets of old, they serve as sources of light, standing before the Lord of the earth. They represent the Church in both dispensations, deriving their light from the Spirit and ministering for the encouragement of the Church in times of apostasy. Their standing before the Lord signifies their acceptance in His sight and their readiness to act for Him. They freely impart the oil of grace and the truth of the Gospel to others, shining as burning lights and ministering in His presence.

These two olive trees and two candlesticks serve as representations of God's faithful witnesses. They derive their light from the Spirit, ministering to the Church in challenging times. Standing before the Lord signifies their acceptance and readiness to act for Him, freely sharing the oil of grace and the Gospel's truth. Like burning lights, they shine and minister in His presence, protecting and transmitting His unction to others. Through their testimony, they assert God's sovereignty over the earth and all within it.

These two olive trees and two candlesticks symbolize God's faithful witnesses, who derive their light from the Spirit and minister to the Church. They stand before the Lord as representatives of the Church, with the responsibility to encourage and testify in times of apostasy. Their standing before the Lord signifies their acceptance and readiness to act for Him. They freely share the oil of grace and the truth of the Gospel, shining as lights and ministering in His presence, continually transmitting His unction to others.

These two olive trees and two candlesticks are God's faithful witnesses representing the Church. They derive their light from the Spirit and minister in times of apostasy. Standing before the Lord, they bear His testimony and provide encouragement. They freely share the oil of grace and the truth of the Gospel, shining as lights and ministering in His presence. Through their witness, they assert God's sovereignty and offer His unction to others, continually transmitting His light to the world.

These two olive trees and two candlesticks embody the faithful witnesses of God, signifying the Church's representative light-bearers. They draw their light from the Spirit, ministering for the Church's encouragement during times of apostasy. Standing before the Lord, they testify to His truth and are accepted in His sight, ready to act on His behalf. The witnesses freely impart the oil of grace and the Gospel's truth, shining as lights, continually transmitting the unction of the Holy One to others in the world.
